name: Middleton HS Block 6
comment info:
WE NOTICE

We noticed that the 23 richest countries make up only 12% of the population. This means somehow the richest 12% of the population produces half of the greenhouse gases.

We also noticed that, even though China is not one of the 23 richest countries, it produces the second most greenhouse gases. This makes sense, because it does a lot of the world’s production and because it is a large country.

Furthermore, we noticed that the graph only takes carbon dioxide into account, but not other greenhouse gases.


WE WONDER

We wonder what criteria a country must fall under to be considered rich and developed. Is richness measured in monetary or natural value? Is it based on the average amount of money per citizen or all of the money that a country has?

We wonder why the United States produces more greenhouse gases than China if China is known for its unclean air and mass production.

We wonder how the graph would change if other greenhouse gases besides carbon dioxide were included.

HOW THIS RELATES TO US

The graph admonishes us to reduce our carbon footprints.

As the U.S. has the greatest carbon dioxide emissions, it shows how much power U.S. citizens like us would have in stopping climate change by changing their actions.

Climate change hits us as teenagers especially hard because we are witnessing first-hand how global warming is affecting us and we will soon be responsible for repairing its harm.

A HEADLINE
The Fault of Rich CO2untries

name: Luke and Matthew
comment info: We noticed that a few amount of developed and advanced countries emit the same amount of CO2 as more than 150 other countries. This shows that the richest and wealthiest countries are most responsible for climate change. We wonder why these richer countries haven't created a strategy to decrease these problems since they are so wealthy?

name: David, Tyler, Thomaz
comment info: I notice that the richest 12 percent of countries contributed to half of the carbon emission. I wonder if this trend will continue to occur, whether the richest countries will increase their wealth or it will decrease.

name: Avery, Anish, Kaan
comment info:
Our initial impressions is that the different boxes represent different countries and their percentage of global Co2 emissions. The yellow boxes are for 23 rich and developed countries and the gray boxes are the other 150 countries. We notice that the countries that represent only 12 percent of the population make up over half the Co2 emissions.

We wonder why a lot of Asian countries like China and South Korea don't count as developed countries. We wonder the same thing for Russia and Poland. We wonder what makes a country developed or not. Finally, we wonder whether the rate of industrialization in a country correlates to a rate of Co2 emissions.

One catchy title for this graph could be "How Rich Countries make Money: A Guide to Destroying the Climate".

name: Kiefer S and Tyler L
comment info:
We notice that this graph displays all time CO2 emissions. Also, International Transport contributes to a large part of all CO2 emissions, even larger than some countries. 
Furthermore, we wonder why 12% of the population accounts for 50% of all emissions. It's also interesting to see that China is not categorized as a rich, developed country in this graph. 
The United States is the largest contributor to CO2 emissions by far. This effects global warming and sea levels will rise. We have to be the generation that makes a change in this global emissions to save our planet, especially reducing the greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S.

Catchy Headline:
The Emission Epidemic - Who's the Largest Contributor to CO2 Emissions?

name: Panagiotis Papanikolaou
comment info:
I think that the graph above is really important and highly valued.
CO2 emissions result undoubtedly in negative circumstances, such as the pollution of our environment and the evolvement of today's reality.
I believe that, according to the graph above, lots of different countries are responsible for this currently debated theme.
However, I notice that the responsibility each has is not equal to its extent, but, in contrast, it may be associated with its population. For instance, Russia, which is a country with a large territorial area, is responsible for CO2 emissions by only 6,8%, whereas United States, which is a country with a very huge population, has 24,6% responsibility.
I am inclined to think that should we all try to reduce our CO2 emissions, we will for sure leapfrog towars a healthier environment.
